height.summary: The height of the displayed resource, in CSS pixels. -- (Absolute values only. NO percentages)

name.name: name
name.summary: The name of valid browsing context (HTML5), or the name of the control (HTML 4).

standby.name: standby
standby.summary: A message that the browser can show while loading the object's implementation and data.

type.name: type
type.summary: The content type of the resource specified by data. At least one of data and type must be defined.

usemap.name: usemap
usemap.summary: A hash-name reference to a map element; that is a '#' followed by the value of a name of a map element.

width.name: width
width.summary: The width of the display resource, in CSS pixels. -- (Absolute values only. NO percentages)

ol.name: ol
ol.summary: The `<ol>` HTML element represents an ordered list of items â€” typically rendered as a numbered list.
ol.contentCategories: Flow content, and if the `<ol>` element's children include at least one li element, palpable content.
ol.permittedContent: Zero or more li, script and template elements.
ol.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content.
ol.permittedAriaRoles: directory, group, listbox, menu, menubar, none, presentation, radiogroup, tablist, toolbar, tree

reversed.name: reversed
reversed.summary: This Boolean attribute specifies that the list's items are in reverse order. Items will be numbered from high to low.

start.name: start
start.summary: An integer to start counting from for the list items. Always an Arabic numeral (1, 2, 3, etc.), even when the numbering `type` is letters or Roman numerals. For example, to start numbering elements from the letter "d" or the Roman numeral "iv," use `start="4"`.

optgroup.name: optgroup
optgroup.summary: The `<optgroup>` HTML element creates a grouping of options within a select element.
optgroup.tagOmission: The start tag is mandatory. The end tag is optional if this element is immediately followed by another `<optgroup>` element, or if the parent element has no more content.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: If this Boolean attribute is set, none of the items in this option group is selectable. Often browsers grey out such control and it won't receive any browsing events, like mouse clicks or focus-related ones.

label.name: label
label.summary: The name of the group of options, which the browser can use when labeling the options in the user interface. This attribute is mandatory if this element is used.

option.name: option
option.summary: The `<option>` HTML element is used to define an item contained in a select, an optgroup, or a datalist element. As such, `<option>` can represent menu items in popups and other lists of items in an HTML document.
option.tagOmission: The start tag is mandatory. The end tag is optional if this element is immediately followed by another `<option>` element or an optgroup, or if the parent element has no more content.
option.permittedParents: A select, an optgroup or a datalist element.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: If this Boolean attribute is set, this option is not checkable. Often browsers grey out such control and it won't receive any browsing event, like mouse clicks or focus-related ones. If this attribute is not set, the element can still be disabled if one of its ancestors is a disabled optgroup element.

label.name: label
label.summary: This attribute is text for the label indicating the meaning of the option. If the `label` attribute isn't defined, its value is that of the element text content.

selected.name: selected
selected.summary: If present, this Boolean attribute indicates that the option is initially selected. If the `<option>` element is the descendant of a select element whose multiple attribute is not set, only one single `<option>` of this select element may have the `selected` attribute.

value.name: value
value.summary: The content of this attribute represents the value to be submitted with the form, should this option be selected. If this attribute is omitted, the value is taken from the text content of the option element.

output.name: output
output.summary: The `<output>` HTML element is a container element into which a site or app can inject the results of a calculation or the outcome of a user action.
output.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, listed, labelable, resettable form-associated element, palpable content.
output.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

for.name: for
for.summary: A space-separated list of other elements' ids, indicating that those elements contributed input values to (or otherwise affected) the calculation.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element to associate the output with (its form owner). The value of this attribute must be the id of a `<form>` in the same document. (If this attribute is not set, the `<output>` is associated with its ancestor `<form>` element, if any.)

name.name: name
name.summary: The element's name. Used in the HTMLFormElement.elements API.

p.name: p
p.summary:
The `

` HTML element represents a paragraph. Paragraphs are usually represented in visual media as blocks of text separated from adjacent blocks by blank lines and/or first-line indentation, but HTML paragraphs can be any structural grouping of related content, such as images or form fields.
p.tagOmission: The start tag is required. The end tag may be omitted if the p element is immediately followed by an address, article, aside, blockquote, div, dl, fieldset, footer, form, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, header, hr, menu, nav, ol, pre, section, table, ul or another p element, or if there is no more content in the parent element and the parent element is not an a element.
p.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content.

param.name: param
param.summary: The `<param>` HTML element defines parameters for an object element.
param.permittedContent: None, it is an empty element.
param.tagOmission: As it is a void element, the start tag must be present and the end tag must not be present.
param.permittedParents: An object before any flow content.

value.name: value
value.summary: Specifies the value of the parameter.

type.name: type
type.summary: Only used if the `valuetype` is set to `ref`. Specifies the MIME type of values found at the URI specified by value.

valuetype.name: valuetype
valuetype.summary: Specifies the type of the `value` attribute. Possible values are.

picture.name: picture
picture.summary: The `<picture>` HTML element contains zero or more source elements and one img element to offer alternative versions of an image for different display/device scenarios.
picture.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, embedded content
picture.permittedContent: Zero or more source elements, followed by one img element, optionally intermixed with script-supporting elements.
picture.permittedParents: Any element that allows embedded content.

plaintext.name: plaintext
plaintext.summary: The `<plaintext>` HTML element renders everything following the start tag as raw text, ignoring any following HTML. There is no closing tag, since everything after it is considered raw text.

portal.name: portal
portal.summary: The `<portal>` HTML element enables the embedding of another HTML page into the current one for the purposes of allowing smoother navigation into new pages.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: Sets the referrer policy to use when requesting the page at the URL given as the value of the `src` attribute.

src.name: src
src.summary: The URL of the page to embed.

pre.name: pre
pre.summary: The `<pre>` HTML element represents preformatted text which is to be presented exactly as written in the HTML file. The text is typically rendered using a non-proportional, or monospaced, font. Whitespace inside this element is displayed as written.
pre.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content.

cols.name: cols
cols.summary: Contains the preferred count of characters that a line should have. It was a non-standard synonym of width. To achieve such an effect, use CSS width instead.

width.name: width
width.summary: Contains the preferred count of characters that a line should have. Though technically still implemented, this attribute has no visual effect; to achieve such an effect, use CSS width instead.

wrap.name: wrap
wrap.summary: Is a hint indicating how the overflow must happen. In modern browser this hint is ignored and no visual effect results in its present; to achieve such an effect, use CSS white-space instead.

progress.name: progress
progress.summary: The `<progress>` HTML element displays an indicator showing the completion progress of a task, typically displayed as a progress bar.
progress.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, labelable content, palpable content.
progress.permittedContent: Phrasing content, but there must be no `<progress>` element among its descendants.
progress.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

q.name: q
q.summary: The `<q>` HTML element indicates that the enclosed text is a short inline quotation. Most modern browsers implement this by surrounding the text in quotation marks. This element is intended for short quotations that don't require paragraph breaks; for long quotations use the blockquote element.
q.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
q.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

cite.name: cite
cite.summary: The value of this attribute is a URL that designates a source document or message for the information quoted. This attribute is intended to point to information explaining the context or the reference for the quote.

rb.name: rb
rb.summary: The `<rb>` HTML element is used to delimit the base text component of a ruby annotation, i.e. the text that is being annotated. One `<rb>` element should wrap each separate atomic segment of the base text.
rb.permittedContent: As a child of a ruby element.
rb.tagOmission: The end tag can be omitted if the element is immediately followed by an rt, rtc, or rp element or another `<rb>` element, or if there is no more content in the parent element.

rp.name: rp
rp.summary: The `<rp>` HTML element is used to provide fall-back parentheses for browsers that do not support display of ruby annotations using the ruby element. One `<rp>` element should enclose each of the opening and closing parentheses that wrap the rt element that contains the annotation's text.
rp.tagOmission: The end tag can be omitted if the element is immediately followed by an rt or another `<rp>` element, or if there is no more content in the parent element.
rp.permittedParents: A ruby element. `<rp>` must be positioned immediately before or after an rt element.

rt.name: rt
rt.summary: The `<rt>` HTML element specifies the ruby text component of a ruby annotation, which is used to provide pronunciation, translation, or transliteration information for East Asian typography. The `<rt>` element must always be contained within a ruby element.
rt.tagOmission: The end tag may be omitted if the `<rt>` element is immediately followed by an `<rt>` or rp element, or if there is no more content in the parent element

rtc.name: rtc
rtc.summary: The `<rtc>` HTML element embraces semantic annotations of characters presented in a ruby of rb elements used inside of ruby element. rb elements can have both pronunciation (rt) and semantic (rtc) annotations.
rtc.tagOmission: The closing tag can be omitted if it is immediately followed by a rb, rtc or rt element opening tag or by its parent closing tag.

ruby.name: ruby
ruby.summary: The `<ruby>` HTML element represents small annotations that are rendered above, below, or next to base text, usually used for showing the pronunciation of East Asian characters. It can also be used for annotating other kinds of text, but this usage is less common.
ruby.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
ruby.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

s.name: s
s.summary: The `<s>` HTML element renders text with a strikethrough, or a line through it. Use the `<s>` element to represent things that are no longer relevant or no longer accurate. However, `<s>` is not appropriate when indicating document edits; for that, use the del and ins elements, as appropriate.
s.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

samp.name: samp
samp.summary: The `<samp>` HTML element is used to enclose inline text which represents sample (or quoted) output from a computer program. Its contents are typically rendered using the browser's default monospaced font (such as wikipedia or Lucida Console).
samp.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
samp.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

script.name: script
script.summary: The `<script>` HTML element is used to embed executable code or data; this is typically used to embed or refer to JavaScript code. The `<script>` element can also be used with other languages, such as WebGL's GLSL shader programming language and JSON.
script.contentCategories: Metadata content, Flow content, Phrasing content.
script.permittedParents: Any element that accepts metadata content, or any element that accepts phrasing content.

async.name: async
async.summary: For classic scripts, if the `async` attribute is present, then the classic script will be fetched in parallel to parsing and evaluated as soon as it is available.

crossorigin.name: crossorigin
crossorigin.summary: Normal `script` elements pass minimal information to the for scripts which do not pass the standard CORS checks. To allow error logging for sites which use a separate domain for static media, use this attribute. See CORS settings attributes for a more descriptive explanation of its valid arguments.

defer.name: defer
defer.summary: This Boolean attribute is set to indicate to a browser that the script is meant to be executed after the document has been parsed, but before firing Document/DOMContentLoaded_event.

fetchpriority.name: fetchpriority
fetchpriority.summary: Provides a hint of the relative priority to use when fetching an external script

integrity.name: integrity
integrity.summary: This attribute contains inline metadata that a user agent can use to verify that a fetched resource has been delivered free of unexpected manipulation. See Subresource Integrity.

nomodule.name: nomodule
nomodule.summary: This Boolean attribute is set to indicate that the script should not be executed in browsers that support ES2015 modules â€” in effect, this can be used to serve fallback scripts to older browsers that do not support modular JavaScript code.

nonce.name: nonce
nonce.summary: A cryptographic nonce (number used once) to allow scripts in a script-src Content-Security-Policy. The server must generate a unique nonce value each time it transmits a policy. It is critical to provide a nonce that cannot be guessed as bypassing a resource's policy is otherwise trivial.

referrerpolicy.name: referrerpolicy
referrerpolicy.summary: Indicates which referrer to send when fetching the script, or resources fetched by the script.

src.name: src
src.summary: This attribute specifies the URI of an external script; this can be used as an alternative to embedding a script directly within a document.

type.name: type
type.summary: This attribute indicates the type of script represented. The value of this attribute will be in one of the following categories.

section.name: section
section.summary: The `<section>` HTML element represents a generic standalone section of a document, which doesn't have a more specific semantic element to represent it. Sections should always have a heading, with very few exceptions.
section.contentCategories: Flow content, Sectioning content, palpable content.
section.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content. Note that a `<section>` element must not be a descendant of an address element.
section.implicitAriaRole: region if the element has an accessible name, otherwise no corresponding role
section.permittedAriaRoles: alert, alertdialog, application, banner, complementary, contentinfo, dialog, document, feed, log, main, marquee, navigation, none, note, presentation, search, status, tabpanel

select.name: select
select.summary: The `<select>` HTML element represents a control that provides a menu of options.
select.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, interactive content, listed, labelable, resettable, and submittable form-associated element
select.permittedContent: Zero or more option or optgroup elements.
select.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.
select.implicitAriaRole: combobox with no multiple attribute and no size attribute greater than 1, otherwise listbox
select.permittedAriaRoles: menu with no multiple attribute and no size attribute greater than 1, otherwise no role permitted

autocomplete.name: autocomplete
autocomplete.summary: A string providing a hint for a user agent autocomplete feature. See The HTML autocomplete attribute for a complete list of values and details on how to use autocomplete.

autofocus.name: autofocus
autofocus.summary: This Boolean attribute lets you specify that a form control should have input focus when the page loads. Only one form element in a document can have the `autofocus` attribute.

disabled.name: disabled
disabled.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates that the user cannot interact with the control. If this attribute is not specified, the control inherits its setting from the containing element, for example fieldset; if there is no containing element with the `disabled` attribute set, then the control is enabled.

form.name: form
form.summary: The form element to associate the `<select>` with (its form owner). The value of this attribute must be the id of a `<form>` in the same document. (If this attribute is not set, the `<select>` is associated with its ancestor `<form>` element, if any.)

multiple.name: multiple
multiple.summary: This Boolean attribute indicates that multiple options can be selected in the list. If it is not specified, then only one option can be selected at a time. When `multiple` is specified, most browsers will show a scrolling list box instead of a single line dropdown.

name.name: name
name.summary: This attribute is used to specify the name of the control.

required.name: required
required.summary: A Boolean attribute indicating that an option with a non-empty string value must be selected.

size.name: size
size.summary: If the control is presented as a scrolling list box (e.g. when `multiple` is specified), this attribute represents the number of rows in the list that should be visible at one time. Browsers are not required to present a select element as a scrolled list box. The default value is `0`.

shadow.name: shadow
shadow.summary: The `<shadow>` HTML elementâ€”an obsolete part of the Web Components technology suiteâ€”was intended to be used as a shadow DOM insertion point. You might have used it if you have created multiple shadow roots under a shadow host. It is not useful in ordinary HTML.
shadow.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content.

slot.name: slot
slot.summary: The `<slot>` HTML elementâ€”part of the Web Components technology suiteâ€”is a placeholder inside a web component that you can fill with your own markup, which lets you create separate DOM trees and present them together.
slot.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content

small.name: small
small.summary: The `<small>` HTML element represents side-comments and small print, like copyright and legal text, independent of its styled presentation. By default, it renders text within it one font-size smaller, such as from `small` to `x-small`.
small.tagOmission: None, must have both a start tag and an end tag.
small.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content, or any element that accepts flow content.

source.name: source
source.summary: The `<source>` HTML element specifies multiple media resources for the picture, the audio element, or the video element. It is an empty element, meaning that it has no content and does not have a closing tag. It is commonly used to offer the same media content in multiple file formats in order to provide compatibility with a broad range of browsers given their differing support for image file formats and media file formats.
source.permittedContent: None, it is an empty element.
source.tagOmission: It must have a start tag, but must not have an end tag.
source.permittedParents: A media elementâ€”audio or videoâ€”and it must be placed before any flow content or track element. A picture element, and it must be placed before the img element.

type.name: type
type.summary: The MIME media type of the resource, optionally with a `codecs` parameter.

src.name: src
src.summary: Required if the `source` element's parent is an audio and video element, but not allowed if the `source` element's parent is a picture element.

srcset.name: srcset
srcset.summary: Required if the `source` element's parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element's parent is an audio or video element.

sizes.name: sizes
sizes.summary: Allowed if the `source` element's parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element's parent is an audio or video element.

media.name: media
media.summary: Allowed if the `source` element's parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element's parent is an audio or video element.

height.name: height
height.summary: Allowed if the `source` element's parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element's parent is an audio or video element.

width.name: width
width.summary: Allowed if the `source` element's parent is a picture element, but not allowed if the `source` element's parent is an audio or video element.

spacer.name: spacer
spacer.summary: The `<spacer>` HTML element is an obsolete HTML element which allowed insertion of empty spaces on pages. It was devised by Netscape to accomplish the same effect as a single-pixel layout image, which was something web designers used to use to add white spaces to web pages without actually using an image. However, `<spacer>` no longer supported by any major browser and the same effects can now be achieved using simple CSS.

span.name: span
span.summary: The `<span>` HTML element is a generic inline container for phrasing content, which does not inherently represent anything. It can be used to group elements for styling purposes (using the class or id attributes), or because they share attribute values, such as lang. It should be used only when no other semantic element is appropriate. `<span>` is very much like a div element, but div is a block-level element whereas a `<span>` is an inline element.
span.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content, or any element that accepts flow content.

strike.name: strike
strike.summary: The `<strike>` HTML element places a strikethrough (horizontal line) over text.

strong.name: strong
strong.summary: The `<strong>` HTML element indicates that its contents have strong importance, seriousness, or urgency. Browsers typically render the contents in bold type.
strong.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
strong.tagOmission: None, must have both a start tag and an end tag.
strong.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content, or any element that accepts flow content.

style.name: style
style.summary: The `<style>` HTML element contains style information for a document, or part of a document. It contains CSS, which is applied to the contents of the document containing the `<style>` element.
style.contentCategories: Metadata content, and if the scoped attribute is present: flow content.
style.permittedContent: Text content matching the type attribute, that is text/css.
style.permittedParents: Any element that accepts metadata content.

media.name: media
media.summary: This attribute defines which media the style should be applied to. Its value is a media query, which defaults to `all` if the attribute is missing.

nonce.name: nonce
nonce.summary: A cryptographic nonce (number used once) used to allow inline styles in a style-src Content-Security-Policy. The server must generate a unique nonce value each time it transmits a policy. It is critical to provide a nonce that cannot be guessed as bypassing a resource's policy is otherwise trivial.

title.name: title
title.summary: This attribute specifies alternative style sheet sets.

sub.name: sub
sub.summary: The `<sub>` HTML element specifies inline text which should be displayed as subscript for solely typographical reasons. Subscripts are typically rendered with a lowered baseline using smaller text.
sub.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
sub.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

summary.name: summary
summary.summary: The `<summary>` HTML element specifies a summary, caption, or legend for a details element's disclosure box. Clicking the `<summary>` element toggles the state of the parent `<details>` element open and closed.
summary.permittedContent: Phrasing content or one element of Heading content
summary.tagOmission: None, both the start tag and the end tag are mandatory.

sup.name: sup
sup.summary: The `<sup>` HTML element specifies inline text which is to be displayed as superscript for solely typographical reasons. Superscripts are usually rendered with a raised baseline using smaller text.
sup.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
sup.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

table.name: table
table.summary: The `<table>` HTML element represents tabular data â€” that is, information presented in a two-dimensional table comprised of rows and columns of cells containing data.
table.permittedContent: In this order: an optional caption element, zero or more colgroup elements, an optional thead element, either one of the following: zero or more tbody elements one or more tr elements an optional tfoot element
table.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content

tbody.name: tbody
tbody.summary: The `<tbody>` HTML element encapsulates a set of table rows (tr elements), indicating that they comprise the body of the table (table).
tbody.tagOmission: The `<tbody>` element is not a required child element for a parent table element to graphically render. However, it must be present, if the parent table element has a thead, a tfoot or another tbody element as a child. If the `<tbody>` element starts with a tbody element, and is not following a non-closed `<tbody>` element, its opening tag can be omitted.
tbody.permittedParents: Within the required parent table element, the `<tbody>` element can be added after a caption, colgroup, and a thead element.

td.name: td
td.summary: The `<td>` HTML element defines a cell of a table that contains data. It participates in the table model.
td.tagOmission: The start tag is mandatory.The end tag may be omitted, if it is immediately followed by a th or td element or if there are no more data in its parent element.
td.implicitAriaRole: cell if a descendant of a table element

colspan.name: colspan
colspan.summary: This attribute contains a non-negative integer value that indicates for how many columns the cell extends. Its default value is `1`. Values higher than 1000 will be considered as incorrect and will be set to the default value (1).

headers.name: headers
headers.summary: This attribute contains a list of space-separated strings, each corresponding to the id attribute of the th elements that apply to this element.

rowspan.name: rowspan
rowspan.summary: This attribute contains a non-negative integer value that indicates for how many rows the cell extends. Its default value is `1`; if its value is set to `0`, it extends until the end of the table section (thead, tbody, tfoot, even if implicitly defined), that the cell belongs to. Values higher than 65534 are clipped down to 65534.

template.name: template
template.summary: The `<template>` HTML element is a mechanism for holding HTML that is not to be rendered immediately when a page is loaded but may be instantiated subsequently during runtime using JavaScript.
template.contentCategories: Metadata content, flow content, phrasing content, script-supporting element
template.permittedParents: Any element that accepts metadata content, phrasing content, or script-supporting elements. Also allowed as a child of a colgroup element that does not have a span attribute.

textarea.name: textarea
textarea.summary: The `<textarea>` HTML element represents a multi-line plain-text editing control, useful when you want to allow users to enter a sizeable amount of free-form text, for example a comment on a review or feedback form.
textarea.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, Interactive content, listed, labelable, resettable, and submittable form-associated element.
textarea.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

autocomplete.name: autocomplete
autocomplete.summary: This attribute indicates whether the value of the control can be automatically completed by the browser. Possible values are.

tfoot.name: tfoot
tfoot.summary: The `<tfoot>` HTML element defines a set of rows summarizing the columns of the table.
tfoot.tagOmission: The start tag is mandatory. The end tag may be omitted if there is no more content in the parent table element.
tfoot.permittedParents: A table element. The tfoot must appear after any caption, colgroup, thead, tbody, or tr element. Note that this is the requirement as of HTML5.In HTML4, the tfoot element cannot be placed after any tbody and tr element. Note that this directly contradicts the above normative requirement from HTML5.

th.name: th
th.summary: The `<th>` HTML element defines a cell as header of a group of table cells. The exact nature of this group is defined by the scope and headers attributes.
th.permittedContent: Flow content, but with no header, footer, sectioning content, or heading content descendants.
th.tagOmission: The start tag is mandatory.The end tag may be omitted, if it is immediately followed by a th or td element or if there are no more data in its parent element.

abbr.name: abbr
abbr.summary: This attribute contains a short abbreviated description of the cell's content. Some user-agents, such as speech readers, may present this description before the content itself.

colspan.name: colspan
colspan.summary: This attribute contains a non-negative integer value that indicates for how many columns the cell extends. Its default value is `1`. Values higher than 1000 will be considered as incorrect and will be set to the default value (1).

headers.name: headers
headers.summary: This attribute contains a list of space-separated strings, each corresponding to the id attribute of the th elements that apply to this element.

rowspan.name: rowspan
rowspan.summary: This attribute contains a non-negative integer value that indicates for how many rows the cell extends. Its default value is `1`; if its value is set to `0`, it extends until the end of the table section (thead, tbody, tfoot, even if implicitly defined), that the cell belongs to. Values higher than 65534 are clipped down to 65534.

scope.name: scope
scope.summary: This enumerated attribute defines the cells that the header (defined in the th) element relates to

thead.name: thead
thead.summary: The `<thead>` HTML element defines a set of rows defining the head of the columns of the table.
thead.tagOmission: The start tag is mandatory. The end tag may be omitted if the thead element is immediately followed by a tbody or tfoot element.
thead.permittedParents: A table element. The thead must appear after any caption or colgroup element, even implicitly defined, but before any tbody, tfoot and tr element.

time.name: time
time.summary: The `<time>` HTML element represents a specific period in time. It may include the `datetime` attribute to translate dates into machine-readable format, allowing for better search engine results or custom features such as reminders.
time.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
time.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

datetime.name: datetime
datetime.summary: This attribute indicates the time and/or date of the element and must be in one of the formats described below.

title.name: title
title.summary: The `<title>` HTML element defines the document's title that is shown in a Browser's title bar or a page's tab. It only contains text; tags within the element are ignored.
title.permittedContent: Text that is not inter-element whitespace.
title.tagOmission: Both opening and closing tags are required. Note that leaving off `</title>` should cause the browser to ignore the rest of the page.
title.permittedParents: A head element that contains no other title element.

tr.name: tr
tr.summary: The `<tr>` HTML element defines a row of cells in a table. The row's cells can then be established using a mix of td (data cell) and th (header cell) elements.
tr.permittedContent: Zero or more td and/or th elements; script-supporting element (script and template) are also allowed
tr.tagOmission: Start tag is mandatory. End tag may be omitted if the tr element is immediately followed by a tr element, or if the row is the last element in its parent table group (thead, tbody or tfoot) element
tr.permittedParents: table (only if the table has no child tbody element, and even then only after any caption, colgroup, and thead elements); otherwise, the parent must be thead, tbody or tfoot

track.name: track
track.summary: The `<track>` HTML element is used as a child of the media elements, audio and video. It lets you specify timed text tracks (or time-based data), for example to automatically handle subtitles. The tracks are formatted in WebVTT format (`.vtt` files) â€” Web Video Text Tracks.
track.permittedContent: None, it is an empty element.
track.tagOmission: As it is a void element, the start tag must be present and the end tag must not be present.
track.permittedParents: A media element, audio or video.

default.name: default
default.summary: This attribute indicates that the track should be enabled unless the user's preferences indicate that another track is more appropriate. This may only be used on one `track` element per media element.

kind.name: kind
kind.summary: How the text track is meant to be used. If omitted the default kind is `subtitles`. If the attribute contains an invalid value, it will use `metadata` (Versions of Chrome earlier than 52 treated an invalid value as `subtitles`). The following keywords are allowed.

label.name: label
label.summary: A user-readable title of the text track which is used by the browser when listing available text tracks.

src.name: src
src.summary: Address of the track (`.vtt` file). Must be a valid URL. This attribute must be specified and its URL value must have the same origin as the document â€” unless the audio or video parent element of the `track` element has a `crossorigin` attribute.

srclang.name: srclang
srclang.summary: Language of the track text data. It must be a valid BCP 47 language tag. If the `kind` attribute is set to `subtitles`, then `srclang` must be defined.

tt.name: tt
tt.summary: The `<tt>` HTML element creates inline text which is presented using the user agent default monospace font face. This element was created for the purpose of rendering text as it would be displayed on a fixed-width display such as a teletype, text-only screen, or line printer.
tt.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
tt.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

u.name: u
u.summary: The `<u>` HTML element represents a span of inline text which should be rendered in a way that indicates that it has a non-textual annotation. This is rendered by default as a simple solid underline, but may be altered using CSS.
u.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
u.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

ul.name: ul
ul.summary: The `<ul>` HTML element represents an unordered list of items, typically rendered as a bulleted list.
ul.contentCategories: Flow content, and if the `<ul>` element's children include at least one li element, palpable content.
ul.permittedContent: Zero or more li, script and template elements.
ul.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content.
ul.permittedAriaRoles: directory, group, listbox, menu, menubar, none, presentation, radiogroup, tablist, toolbar, tree

var.name: var
var.summary: The `<var>` HTML element represents the name of a variable in a mathematical expression or a programming context. It's typically presented using an italicized version of the current typeface, although that behavior is browser-dependent.
var.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, palpable content.
var.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

video.name: video
video.summary: The `<video>` HTML element embeds a media player which supports video playback into the document. You can use `<video>` for audio content as well, but the audio element may provide a more appropriate user experience.
video.contentCategories: Flow content, phrasing content, embedded content. If it has a controls attribute: interactive content and palpable content.
video.permittedContent: If the element has a src attribute: zero or more track elements, followed by transparent content that contains no media elementsâ€“that is no audio or video Else: zero or more source elements, followed by zero or more track elements, followed by transparent content that contains no media elementsâ€“that is no audio or video.
video.permittedParents: Any element that accepts embedded content.

autoplay.name: autoplay
autoplay.summary: A Boolean attribute; if specified, the video automatically begins to play back as soon as it can do so without stopping to finish loading the data.

autopictureinpicture.name: autopictureinpicture
autopictureinpicture.summary: A Boolean attribute which if `true` indicates that the element should automatically toggle picture-in-picture mode when the user switches back and forth between this document and another document or application.

controls.name: controls
controls.summary: If this attribute is present, the browser will offer controls to allow the user to control video playback, including volume, seeking, and pause/resume playback.

controlslist.name: controlslist
controlslist.summary: The `controlslist` attribute, when specified, helps the browser select what controls to show on the media element whenever the browser shows its own set of controls (e.g. when the `controls` attribute is specified).

crossorigin.name: crossorigin
crossorigin.summary: This enumerated attribute indicates whether to use CORS to fetch the related video. CORS-enabled resources can be reused in the canvas element without being tainted. The allowed values are.

disablepictureinpicture.name: disablepictureinpicture
disablepictureinpicture.summary: Prevents the browser from suggesting a Picture-in-Picture context menu or to request Picture-in-Picture automatically in some cases.

disableremoteplayback.name: disableremoteplayback
disableremoteplayback.summary: A Boolean attribute used to disable the capability of remote playback in devices that are attached using wired (HDMI, DVI, etc.) and wireless technologies (Miracast, Chromecast, DLNA, AirPlay, etc).

height.name: height
height.summary: The height of the video's display area, in CSS pixels (absolute values only; no percentages.)

loop.name: loop
loop.summary: A Boolean attribute; if specified, the browser will automatically seek back to the start upon reaching the end of the video.

muted.name: muted
muted.summary: A Boolean attribute that indicates the default setting of the audio contained in the video. If set, the audio will be initially silenced. Its default value is `false`, meaning that the audio will be played when the video is played.

playsinline.name: playsinline
playsinline.summary: A Boolean attribute indicating that the video is to be played "inline", that is within the element's playback area. Note that the absence of this attribute does not imply that the video will always be played in fullscreen.

poster.name: poster
poster.summary: A URL for an image to be shown while the video is downloading. If this attribute isn't specified, nothing is displayed until the first frame is available, then the first frame is shown as the poster frame.

preload.name: preload
preload.summary: This enumerated attribute is intended to provide a hint to the browser about what the author thinks will lead to the best user experience with regards to what content is loaded before the video is played

src.name: src
src.summary: The URL of the video to embed. This is optional; you may instead use the source element within the video block to specify the video to embed.

width.name: width
width.summary: The width of the video's display area, in CSS pixels (absolute values only; no percentages).

wbr.name: wbr
wbr.summary: The `<wbr>` HTML element represents a word break opportunityâ€”a position within text where the browser may optionally break a line, though its line-breaking rules would not otherwise create a break at that location.
wbr.tagOmission: It is an empty element; it must have a start tag, but must not have an end tag.
wbr.permittedParents: Any element that accepts phrasing content.

xmp.name: xmp
xmp.summary: The `<xmp>` HTML element renders text between the start and end tags without interpreting the HTML in between and using a monospaced font. The HTML2 specification recommended that it should be rendered wide enough to allow 80 characters per line.

h1.name: h6
h1.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.
h1.contentCategories: Flow content, heading content, palpable content.
h1.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content; don't use a heading element as a child of the hgroup element â€” it is now deprecated.

h2.name: h6
h2.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.
h2.contentCategories: Flow content, heading content, palpable content.
h2.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content; don't use a heading element as a child of the hgroup element â€” it is now deprecated.

h3.name: h6
h3.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.
h3.contentCategories: Flow content, heading content, palpable content.
h3.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content; don't use a heading element as a child of the hgroup element â€” it is now deprecated.

h4.name: h6
h4.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.
h4.contentCategories: Flow content, heading content, palpable content.
h4.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content; don't use a heading element as a child of the hgroup element â€” it is now deprecated.

h5.name: h6
h5.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.
h5.contentCategories: Flow content, heading content, palpable content.
h5.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content; don't use a heading element as a child of the hgroup element â€” it is now deprecated.

h6.name: h6
h6.summary: The `<h1>` to `<h6>` HTML elements represent six levels of section headings. `<h1>` is the highest section level and `<h6>` is the lowest.
h6.contentCategories: Flow content, heading content, palpable content.
h6.permittedParents: Any element that accepts flow content; don't use a heading element as a child of the hgroup element â€” it is now deprecated.

a.name: a
a.summary: The <a> SVG element creates a hyperlink to other web pages, files, locations in the same page, email addresses, or any other URL. It is very similar to HTML's a element.

href.name: href
href.summary: The `href` attribute defines a link to a resource as a reference URL. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

target.name: target
target.summary: The `target` attribute should be used when there are multiple possible targets for the ending resource, such as when the parent document is embedded within an HTML or XHTML document, or is viewed with a tabbed browser. This attribute specifies the name of the browsing context (e.g., a browser tab or an (X)HTML iframe or object element) into which a document is to be opened when the link is activated.

xlink:href.name: xlink:href
xlink:href.summary: The `xlink:href` attribute defines a reference to a resource as a reference IRI. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

altGlyph.name: altGlyph
altGlyph.summary: The `<altGlyph>` SVG element allows sophisticated selection of the glyphs used to render its child character data.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

dx.name: dx
dx.summary: The `dx` attribute indicates a shift along the x-axis on the position of an element or its content.

dy.name: dy
dy.summary: The `dy` attribute indicates a shift along the y-axis on the position of an element or its content.

rotate.name: rotate
rotate.summary: The `rotate` attribute specifies how the animated element rotates as it travels along a path specified in an animateMotion element.

glyphRef.name: glyphRef
glyphRef.summary: The `glyphRef` attribute represents the glyph identifier, the format of which is dependent on the format of the given font.

format.name: format
format.summary: The `format` attribute indicates the format of the given font.

xlink:href.name: xlink:href
xlink:href.summary: The `xlink:href` attribute defines a reference to a resource as a reference IRI. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

altGlyphDef.name: altGlyphDef
altGlyphDef.summary: The `<altGlyphDef>` SVG element defines a substitution representation for glyphs.

altGlyphItem.name: altGlyphItem
altGlyphItem.summary: The `<altGlyphItem>` element provides a set of candidates for glyph substitution by the altGlyph element.

animate.name: animate
animate.summary: The SVG `<animate>` element provides a way to animate an attribute of an element over time.

animateMotion.name: animateMotion
animateMotion.summary: The SVG `<animateMotion>` element provides a way to define how an element moves along a motion path.

keyPoints.name: keyPoints
keyPoints.summary: The `keyPoints` attribute indicates the simple duration of an animation.

path.name: path
path.summary: The `path` attribute has two different meanings, either it defines a text path along which the characters of a text are rendered, or a motion path along which a referenced element is animated.

rotate.name: rotate
rotate.summary: The `rotate` attribute specifies how the animated element rotates as it travels along a path specified in an animateMotion element.

animateTransform.name: animateTransform
animateTransform.summary: The `animateTransform` element animates a transformation attribute on its target element, thereby allowing animations to control translation, scaling, rotation, and/or skewing.

circle.name: circle
circle.summary: The `<circle>` SVG element is an SVG basic shape, used to draw circles based on a center point and a radius.

cx.name: cx
cx.summary: The `cx` attribute define the x-axis coordinate of a center point.

cy.name: cy
cy.summary: The `cy` attribute define the y-axis coordinate of a center point.

r.name: r
r.summary: The `r` attribute defines the radius of a circle.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

clipPath.name: clipPath
clipPath.summary: The `<clipPath>` SVG element defines a clipping path, to be used by the clip-path property.

clipPathUnits.name: clipPathUnits
clipPathUnits.summary: The `clipPathUnits` attribute indicates which coordinate system to use for the contents of the clipPath element.

cursor.name: cursor
cursor.summary: Note: The CSS cursor property should be used instead of this element.

defs.name: defs
defs.summary: The `<defs>` element is used to store graphical objects that will be used at a later time. Objects created inside a `<defs>` element are not rendered directly. To display them you have to reference them (with a use element for example).

desc.name: desc
desc.summary: The `<desc>` element provides an accessible, long-text description of any SVG container element or graphics element.

discard.name: discard
discard.summary: The `<discard>` SVG element allows authors to specify the time at which particular elements are to be discarded, thereby reducing the resources required by an SVG user agent. This is particularly useful to help SVG viewers conserve memory while displaying long-running documents.

ellipse.name: ellipse
ellipse.summary: The `<ellipse>` element is an SVG basic shape, used to create ellipses based on a center coordinate, and both their x and y radius.

cx.name: cx
cx.summary: The `cx` attribute define the x-axis coordinate of a center point.

cy.name: cy
cy.summary: The `cy` attribute define the y-axis coordinate of a center point.

rx.name: rx
rx.summary: The `rx` attribute defines a radius on the x-axis.

ry.name: ry
ry.summary: The `ry` attribute defines a radius on the y-axis.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

feBlend.name: feBlend
feBlend.summary: The `<feBlend>` SVG filter primitive composes two objects together ruled by a certain blending mode. This is similar to what is known from image editing software when blending two layers. The mode is defined by the mode attribute.

feColorMatrix.name: feColorMatrix
feColorMatrix.summary: The `<feColorMatrix>` SVG filter element changes colors based on a transformation matrix. Every pixel's color value `[R,G,B,A]` is matrix multiplied by a 5 by 5 color matrix to create new color `[R',G',B',A']`.

feComponentTransfer.name: feComponentTransfer
feComponentTransfer.summary: The `<feComponentTransfer>` SVG filter primitive performs color-component-wise remapping of data for each pixel. It allows operations like brightness adjustment, contrast adjustment, color balance or thresholding.

feComposite.name: feComposite
feComposite.summary: The `<feComposite>` SVG filter primitive performs the combination of two input images pixel-wise in image space using one of the Porter-Duff compositing operations: `over`, `in`, `atop`, `out`, `xor`, `lighter`, or `arithmetic`.

feConvolveMatrix.name: feConvolveMatrix
feConvolveMatrix.summary: The `<feConvolveMatrix>` SVG filter primitive applies a matrix convolution filter effect. A convolution combines pixels in the input image with neighboring pixels to produce a resulting image. A wide variety of imaging operations can be achieved through convolutions, including blurring, edge detection, sharpening, embossing and beveling.

feDiffuseLighting.name: feDiffuseLighting
feDiffuseLighting.summary: The `<feDiffuseLighting>` SVG filter primitive lights an image using the alpha channel as a bump map. The resulting image, which is an RGBA opaque image, depends on the light color, light position and surface geometry of the input bump map.

feDisplacementMap.name: feDisplacementMap
feDisplacementMap.summary: The `<feDisplacementMap>` SVG filter primitive uses the pixel values from the image from in2 to spatially displace the image from in.

feDistantLight.name: feDistantLight
feDistantLight.summary: The `<feDistantLight>` filter primitive defines a distant light source that can be used within a lighting filter primitive: feDiffuseLighting or feSpecularLighting.

feDropShadow.name: feDropShadow
feDropShadow.summary: The SVG `<feDropShadow>` filter primitive creates a drop shadow of the input image. It can only be used inside a element.

dx.name: dx
dx.summary: The `dx` attribute indicates a shift along the x-axis on the position of an element or its content.

dy.name: dy
dy.summary: The `dy` attribute indicates a shift along the y-axis on the position of an element or its content.

stdDeviation.name: stdDeviation
stdDeviation.summary: The `stdDeviation` attribute defines the standard deviation for the blur operation.

feFlood.name: feFlood
feFlood.summary: The `<feFlood>` SVG filter primitive fills the filter subregion with the color and opacity defined by flood-color and flood-opacity.

feFuncA.name: feFuncA
feFuncA.summary: The `<feFuncA>` SVG filter primitive defines the transfer function for the alpha component of the input graphic of its parent feComponentTransfer element.

feFuncB.name: feFuncB
feFuncB.summary: The `<feFuncB>` SVG filter primitive defines the transfer function for the blue component of the input graphic of its parent feComponentTransfer element.

feFuncG.name: feFuncG
feFuncG.summary: The `<feFuncG>` SVG filter primitive defines the transfer function for the green component of the input graphic of its parent feComponentTransfer element.

feFuncR.name: feFuncR
feFuncR.summary: The `<feFuncR>` SVG filter primitive defines the transfer function for the red component of the input graphic of its parent feComponentTransfer element.

feGaussianBlur.name: feGaussianBlur
feGaussianBlur.summary: The `<feGaussianBlur>` SVG filter primitive blurs the input image by the amount specified in stdDeviation, which defines the bell-curve.

feImage.name: feImage
feImage.summary: The `<feImage>` SVG filter primitive fetches image data from an external source and provides the pixel data as output (meaning if the external source is an SVG image, it is rasterized.)

feMerge.name: feMerge
feMerge.summary: The `<feMerge>` SVG element allows filter effects to be applied concurrently instead of sequentially. This is achieved by other filters storing their output via the result attribute and then accessing it in a feMergeNode child.

feMergeNode.name: feMergeNode
feMergeNode.summary: The `feMergeNode` takes the result of another filter to be processed by its parent feMerge.

feMorphology.name: feMorphology
feMorphology.summary: The `<feMorphology>` SVG filter primitive is used to erode or dilate the input image. Its usefulness lies especially in fattening or thinning effects.

feOffset.name: feOffset
feOffset.summary: The `<feOffset>` SVG filter primitive allows to offset the input image. The input image as a whole is offset by the values specified in the dx and dy attributes.

fePointLight.name: fePointLight
fePointLight.summary: The `<fePointLight>` filter primitive defines a light source which allows to create a point light effect. It that can be used within a lighting filter primitive: feDiffuseLighting or feSpecularLighting.

feSpecularLighting.name: feSpecularLighting
feSpecularLighting.summary: The `<feSpecularLighting>` SVG filter primitive lights a source graphic using the alpha channel as a bump map. The resulting image is an RGBA image based on the light color. The lighting calculation follows the standard specular component of the Phong lighting model. The resulting image depends on the light color, light position and surface geometry of the input bump map. The result of the lighting calculation is added. The filter primitive assumes that the viewer is at infinity in the z direction.

feSpotLight.name: feSpotLight
feSpotLight.summary: The `<feSpotLight>` SVG filter primitive defines a light source that can be used to create a spotlight effect. It is used within a lighting filter primitive: feDiffuseLighting or feSpecularLighting.

feTile.name: feTile
feTile.summary: The `<feTile>` SVG filter primitive allows to fill a target rectangle with a repeated, tiled pattern of an input image. The effect is similar to the one of a pattern.

feTurbulence.name: feTurbulence
feTurbulence.summary: The `<feTurbulence>` SVG filter primitive creates an image using the Perlin turbulence function. It allows the synthesis of artificial textures like clouds or marble. The resulting image will fill the entire filter primitive subregion.

filter.name: filter
filter.summary: The `<filter>` SVG element defines a custom filter effect by grouping atomic filter primitives. It is never rendered itself, but must be used by the filter attribute on SVG elements, or the filter CSS property for SVG/HTML elements.

font.name: font
font.summary: The `<font>` SVG element defines a font to be used for text layout.

font-face.name: font-face
font-face.summary: The `<font-face>` SVG element corresponds to the CSS @font-face rule. It defines a font's outer properties.

font-face-format.name: font-face-format
font-face-format.summary: The `<font-face-format>` SVG element describes the type of font referenced by its parent font-face-uri.

font-face-name.name: font-face-name
font-face-name.summary: The `<font-face-name>` element points to a locally installed copy of this font, identified by its name.

font-face-src.name: font-face-src
font-face-src.summary: The `<font-face-src>` SVG element corresponds to the @font-face/src descriptor in CSS @font-face rules. It serves as container for font-face-name, pointing to locally installed copies of this font, and font-face-uri, utilizing remotely defined fonts.

font-face-uri.name: font-face-uri
font-face-uri.summary: The `<font-face-uri>` SVG element points to a remote definition of the current font.

foreignObject.name: foreignObject
foreignObject.summary: The `<foreignObject>` SVG element includes elements from a different XML namespace. In the context of a browser, it is most likely (X)HTML.

height.name: height
height.summary: The `height` attribute defines the vertical length of an element in the user coordinate system.

width.name: width
width.summary: The `width` attribute defines the horizontal length of an element in the user coordinate system.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

g.name: g
g.summary: The `<g>` SVG element is a container used to group other SVG elements.

glyph.name: glyph
glyph.summary: A `<glyph>` defines a single glyph in an SVG font.

glyphRef.name: glyphRef
glyphRef.summary: The `glyphRef` element provides a single possible glyph to the referencing altGlyph substitution.

hkern.name: hkern
hkern.summary: The `<hkern>` SVG element allows to fine-tweak the horizontal distance between two glyphs. This process is known as kerning.

image.name: image
image.summary: The `<image>` SVG element includes images inside SVG documents. It can display raster image files or other SVG files.

line.name: line
line.summary: The `<line>` element is an SVG basic shape used to create a line connecting two points.

x1.name: x1
x1.summary: The `x1` attribute is used to specify the first x-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the x attribute instead.

x2.name: x2
x2.summary: The `x2` attribute is used to specify the second x-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the x attribute instead.

y1.name: y1
y1.summary: The `y1` attribute is used to specify the first y-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the y attribute instead.

y2.name: y2
y2.summary: The `y2` attribute is used to specify the second y-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the y attribute instead.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

linearGradient.name: linearGradient
linearGradient.summary: The `<linearGradient>` element lets authors define linear gradients to apply to other SVG elements.

gradientUnits.name: gradientUnits
gradientUnits.summary: The `gradientUnits` attribute defines the coordinate system used for attributes specified on the gradient elements.

gradientTransform.name: gradientTransform
gradientTransform.summary: The `gradientTransform` attribute contains the definition of an optional additional transformation from the gradient coordinate system onto the target coordinate system (i.e., userSpaceOnUse or objectBoundingBox). This allows for things such as skewing the gradient. This additional transformation matrix is post-multiplied to (i.e., inserted to the right of) any previously defined transformations, including the implicit transformation necessary to convert from object bounding box units to user space.

href.name: href
href.summary: The `href` attribute defines a link to a resource as a reference URL. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

spreadMethod.name: spreadMethod
spreadMethod.summary: The `spreadMethod` attribute determines how a shape is filled beyond the defined edges of a gradient.

x1.name: x1
x1.summary: The `x1` attribute is used to specify the first x-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the x attribute instead.

x2.name: x2
x2.summary: The `x2` attribute is used to specify the second x-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the x attribute instead.

xlink:href.name: xlink:href
xlink:href.summary: The `xlink:href` attribute defines a reference to a resource as a reference IRI. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

y1.name: y1
y1.summary: The `y1` attribute is used to specify the first y-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the y attribute instead.

y2.name: y2
y2.summary: The `y2` attribute is used to specify the second y-coordinate for drawing an SVG element that requires more than one coordinate. Elements that only need one coordinate use the y attribute instead.

marker.name: marker
marker.summary: The `<marker>` element defines the graphic that is to be used for drawing arrowheads or polymarkers on a given path, line, polyline or polygon element.

markerHeight.name: markerHeight
markerHeight.summary: The `markerHeight` attribute represents the height of the viewport into which the marker is to be fitted when it is rendered according to the viewBox and preserveAspectRatio attributes.

markerUnits.name: markerUnits
markerUnits.summary: The `markerUnits` attribute defines the coordinate system for the markerWidth and markerHeight attributes and the contents of the marker.

markerWidth.name: markerWidth
markerWidth.summary: The `markerWidth` attribute represents the width of the viewport into which the marker is to be fitted when it is rendered according to the viewBox and preserveAspectRatio attributes.

orient.name: orient
orient.summary: The `orient` attribute indicates how a marker is rotated when it is placed at its position on the shape.

preserveAspectRatio.name: preserveAspectRatio
preserveAspectRatio.summary: The `preserveAspectRatio` attribute indicates how an element with a viewBox providing a given aspect ratio must fit into a viewport with a different aspect ratio.

refX.name: refX
refX.summary: The `refX` attribute defines the x coordinate of an element's reference point.

refY.name: refY
refY.summary: The `refY` attribute defines the y coordinate of an element's reference point.

viewBox.name: viewBox
viewBox.summary: The `viewBox` attribute defines the position and dimension, in user space, of an SVG viewport.

mask.name: mask
mask.summary: The `<mask>` element defines an alpha mask for compositing the current object into the background. A mask is used/referenced using the mask property.

height.name: height
height.summary: The `height` attribute defines the vertical length of an element in the user coordinate system.

maskContentUnits.name: maskContentUnits
maskContentUnits.summary: The `maskContentUnits` attribute indicates which coordinate system to use for the contents of the mask element.

maskUnits.name: maskUnits
maskUnits.summary: The `maskUnits` attribute indicates which coordinate system to use for the geometry properties of the mask element.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

width.name: width
width.summary: The `width` attribute defines the horizontal length of an element in the user coordinate system.

metadata.name: metadata
metadata.summary: The `<metadata>` SVG element adds metadata to SVG content. Metadata is structured information about data. The contents of `<metadata>` should be elements from other XML namespace such as RDF, FOAF, etc.

missing-glyph.name: missing-glyph
missing-glyph.summary: The `<missing-glyph>` SVG element's content is rendered, if for a given character the font doesn't define an appropriate glyph.

mpath.name: mpath
mpath.summary: The `<mpath>` sub-element for the animateMotion element provides the ability to reference an external path element as the definition of a motion path.

path.name: path
path.summary: The `<path>` SVG element is the generic element to define a shape. All the basic shapes can be created with a path element.

d.name: d
d.summary: The `d` attribute defines a path to be drawn.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

pattern.name: pattern
pattern.summary: The `<pattern>` element defines a graphics object which can be redrawn at repeated x- and y-coordinate intervals ("tiled") to cover an area.

height.name: height
height.summary: The `height` attribute defines the vertical length of an element in the user coordinate system.

href.name: href
href.summary: The `href` attribute defines a link to a resource as a reference URL. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

patternContentUnits.name: patternContentUnits
patternContentUnits.summary: The `patternContentUnits` attribute indicates which coordinate system to use for the contents of the pattern element.

patternTransform.name: patternTransform
patternTransform.summary: The `patternTransform` attribute defines a list of transform definitions that are applied to a pattern tile.

patternUnits.name: patternUnits
patternUnits.summary: The `patternUnits` attribute indicates which coordinate system to use for the geometry properties of the pattern element.

preserveAspectRatio.name: preserveAspectRatio
preserveAspectRatio.summary: The `preserveAspectRatio` attribute indicates how an element with a viewBox providing a given aspect ratio must fit into a viewport with a different aspect ratio.

viewBox.name: viewBox
viewBox.summary: The `viewBox` attribute defines the position and dimension, in user space, of an SVG viewport.

width.name: width
width.summary: The `width` attribute defines the horizontal length of an element in the user coordinate system.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

xlink:href.name: xlink:href
xlink:href.summary: The `xlink:href` attribute defines a reference to a resource as a reference IRI. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

polygon.name: polygon
polygon.summary: The `<polygon>` element defines a closed shape consisting of a set of connected straight line segments. The last point is connected to the first point.

points.name: points
points.summary: The `points` attribute defines a list of points. Each point is defined by a pair of number representing a X and a Y coordinate in the user coordinate system. If the attribute contains an odd number of coordinates, the last one will be ignored.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

polyline.name: polyline
polyline.summary: The `<polyline>` SVG element is an SVG basic shape that creates straight lines connecting several points. Typically a `polyline` is used to create open shapes as the last point doesn't have to be connected to the first point. For closed shapes see the polygon element.

points.name: points
points.summary: The `points` attribute defines a list of points. Each point is defined by a pair of number representing a X and a Y coordinate in the user coordinate system. If the attribute contains an odd number of coordinates, the last one will be ignored.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

radialGradient.name: radialGradient
radialGradient.summary: The `<radialGradient>` element lets authors define radial gradients that can be applied to fill or stroke of graphical elements.

cx.name: cx
cx.summary: The `cx` attribute define the x-axis coordinate of a center point.

cy.name: cy
cy.summary: The `cy` attribute define the y-axis coordinate of a center point.

fr.name: fr
fr.summary: The `fr` attribute defines the radius of the focal point for the radial gradient.

fx.name: fx
fx.summary: The `fx` attribute defines the x-axis coordinate of the focal point for a radial gradient.

fy.name: fy
fy.summary: The `fy` attribute defines the y-axis coordinate of the focal point for a radial gradient.

gradientUnits.name: gradientUnits
gradientUnits.summary: The `gradientUnits` attribute defines the coordinate system used for attributes specified on the gradient elements.

gradientTransform.name: gradientTransform
gradientTransform.summary: The `gradientTransform` attribute contains the definition of an optional additional transformation from the gradient coordinate system onto the target coordinate system (i.e., userSpaceOnUse or objectBoundingBox). This allows for things such as skewing the gradient. This additional transformation matrix is post-multiplied to (i.e., inserted to the right of) any previously defined transformations, including the implicit transformation necessary to convert from object bounding box units to user space.

href.name: href
href.summary: The `href` attribute defines a link to a resource as a reference URL. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

r.name: r
r.summary: The `r` attribute defines the radius of a circle.

spreadMethod.name: spreadMethod
spreadMethod.summary: The `spreadMethod` attribute determines how a shape is filled beyond the defined edges of a gradient.

xlink:href.name: xlink:href
xlink:href.summary: The `xlink:href` attribute defines a reference to a resource as a reference IRI. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

rect.name: rect
rect.summary: The `<rect>` element is a basic SVG shape that draws rectangles, defined by their position, width, and height. The rectangles may have their corners rounded.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

width.name: width
width.summary: The `width` attribute defines the horizontal length of an element in the user coordinate system.

height.name: height
height.summary: The `height` attribute defines the vertical length of an element in the user coordinate system.

rx.name: rx
rx.summary: The `rx` attribute defines a radius on the x-axis.

ry.name: ry
ry.summary: The `ry` attribute defines a radius on the y-axis.

pathLength.name: pathLength
pathLength.summary: The `pathLength` attribute lets authors specify a total length for the path, in user units. This value is then used to calibrate the browser's distance calculations with those of the author, by scaling all distance computations using the ratio `pathLength`/(computed value of path length).

script.name: script
script.summary: The SVG `script` element allows to add scripts to an SVG document.

href.name: href
href.summary: The `href` attribute defines a link to a resource as a reference URL. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

type.name: type
type.summary: The `type` attribute is a generic attribute and it has different meaning based on the context in which it's used.

xlink:href.name: xlink:href
xlink:href.summary: The `xlink:href` attribute defines a reference to a resource as a reference IRI. The exact meaning of that link depends on the context of each element using it.

set.name: set
set.summary: The SVG `<set>` element provides a simple means of just setting the value of an attribute for a specified duration.

to.name: to
to.summary: The `to` attribute indicates the final value of the attribute that will be modified during the animation.

stop.name: stop
stop.summary: The SVG `<stop>` element defines a color and its position to use on a gradient. This element is always a child of a linearGradient or radialGradient element.

offset.name: offset
offset.summary: This attribute defines where the gradient stop is placed along the gradient vector.

stop-color.name: stop-color
stop-color.summary: The `stop-color` attribute indicates what color to use at a gradient stop.

stop-opacity.name: stop-opacity
stop-opacity.summary: The `stop-opacity` attribute defines the opacity of a given color gradient stop.

style.name: style
style.summary: The SVG `<style>` element allows style sheets to be embedded directly within SVG content.

type.name: type
type.summary: The `type` attribute is a generic attribute and it has different meaning based on the context in which it's used.

media.name: media
media.summary: The `media` attribute specifies a media query that must be matched for a style sheet to apply.

title.name: title
title.summary: This attribute the title of the style sheet which can be used to switch between alternate style sheets.

svg.name: svg
svg.summary: The `svg` element is a container that defines a new coordinate system and viewport. It is used as the outermost element of SVG documents, but it can also be used to embed an SVG fragment inside an SVG or HTML document.

baseProfile.name: baseProfile
baseProfile.summary: The `baseProfile` attribute describes the minimum SVG language profile that the author believes is necessary to correctly render the content. The attribute does not specify any processing restrictions; It can be considered metadata.

contentScriptType.name: contentScriptType
contentScriptType.summary: The `contentScriptType` attribute specifies the default scripting language for the given document fragment on the svg element.

contentStyleType.name: contentStyleType
contentStyleType.summary: The `contentStyleType` attribute specifies the style sheet language for the given document fragment on the svg element.

height.name: height
height.summary: The `height` attribute defines the vertical length of an element in the user coordinate system.

preserveAspectRatio.name: preserveAspectRatio
preserveAspectRatio.summary: The `preserveAspectRatio` attribute indicates how an element with a viewBox providing a given aspect ratio must fit into a viewport with a different aspect ratio.

version.name: version
version.summary: The `version` attribute is used to indicate what specification a SVG document conforms to. It is only allowed on the root svg element. It is purely advisory and has no influence on rendering or processing.

viewBox.name: viewBox
viewBox.summary: The `viewBox` attribute defines the position and dimension, in user space, of an SVG viewport.

width.name: width
width.summary: The `width` attribute defines the horizontal length of an element in the user coordinate system.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

switch.name: switch
switch.summary: The `<switch>` SVG element evaluates any requiredFeatures, requiredExtensions and systemLanguage attributes on its direct child elements in order, and then renders the first child where these attributes evaluate to true.

symbol.name: symbol
symbol.summary: The `<symbol>` element is used to define graphical template objects which can be instantiated by a use element.

height.name: height
height.summary: The `height` attribute defines the vertical length of an element in the user coordinate system.

preserveAspectRatio.name: preserveAspectRatio
preserveAspectRatio.summary: The `preserveAspectRatio` attribute indicates how an element with a viewBox providing a given aspect ratio must fit into a viewport with a different aspect ratio.

refX.name: refX
refX.summary: The `refX` attribute defines the x coordinate of an element's reference point.

refY.name: refY
refY.summary: The `refY` attribute defines the y coordinate of an element's reference point.

viewBox.name: viewBox
viewBox.summary: The `viewBox` attribute defines the position and dimension, in user space, of an SVG viewport.

width.name: width
width.summary: The `width` attribute defines the horizontal length of an element in the user coordinate system.

x.name: x
x.summary: The `x` attribute defines an x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

y.name: y
y.summary: The `y` attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.

text.name: text
